1.play: Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY, of the house of Capulet, armed with swords and bucklers

2.play: SAMPSON : Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.
notes: Steevens: carry coals] Warburton observes that this was a phrase formerly in use to signify the bearing of injuries; but, as he gives no instances, I subjoin the following. Nash in his Have With you to Saffron Walden, 1595, says: “We will bear no coles, I warrant you.” Again, in Marston’s Antonio and Mellida, second part, 1602: “He has had wrongs; and if I were he I would bear no coles." Again, in Law Tricks, by John Day, 1608: “I’ll carry coals an you will, no horns.” In May-Day, by Chapman, 1610 [in Sing., 1605]: “You must swear by no man’s beard but your own, for that may breed a quarrel; above all things you must carry no coals." “ Now, my ancient being a man of an un-coal-carrying spirit,” etc. Again, in Ben Jonson’s Every Man out of his Humour; “Here comes one that will carry coals; ergo, will hold my dog.” [Cham.] In Hen. V; III, ii, 49: “At Calais they stole a fire-shovel; I knew by that piece of service the men would carry coals," [Sing. Huds.] Again, in The Malcontent, 1604: “ Great slaves fear better than love, born naturally for a coal-basket," \Jlal. Percy. This phrase continued in use to the middle of the last century. In a little satirical piece of Sir John Birkenhead, entitled Two Centuries [of books] of St. Paul’s Churchyard, etc., published after the death of King Charles I, No. 22, p. 50, is inserted Fire! fire! a small manual, dedicated to Sir Arthur Haselridge; in which it is plainly proved by a whole chauldron of Scripture that John Lillburn will not carry coals!' By Dr. Gouge. \Hal. Narks. The origin of the phrase is this, that in every family the scullions, the turnspits, the carriers of wood and coals were esteemed the very lowest of menials. The latter in particular were the servi servorum, the drudges of all the rest. Such attendants upon the royal households in progresses were jocularly called the “ black-guard,” and hence the origin of that term. [Sing. Huds.] In most of these cases charcoal is probably meant.

3.play: GREGORY : No, for then we should be colliers.
notes: Knt.: Upon a passage in Ben Jonson’s “Every Man out of his Humour,” Gifford has this note; “ In all great houses, but particularly in the royal residences, there were a number of mean and dirty dependants whose office it was to attend to the wood-yard and sculleries, etc. Of these (for in the lowest deep there was a deeper still), the most forlorn wretches seem to have been selected to carry coals to the kitchen, halls, etc. To this smutty regiment, who attended the progresses and rode in the cart with the pots and kettles, which, with every other article of furniture, were then moved from palace to palace, the people in derision gave the name of blackguards, a term since become familiar, and never properly explained.” [Com. Sta. Dyce.] In this passage from Ben Jonson, we find the primary meaning of the expression—that of being fit for servile offices; in a subsequent passage we have the secondary meaning—that of tamely submitting to an affront. Puntarvolo insults Shift, who, he supposes, has taken his dog; upon which another character exclaims: “ Take heed, Sir Puntarvolo, what you do! he’ll bear no coals, I can tell you.” Gifford gives an illustration of this meaning (which is the sense in which Sh. here uses it); —“ the queen was exceedingly well satisfied: saying that you were too like some body in the world, to whom she is afrayde you are a little kin, to be content to carry coales at any Frenchman’s hand.” Secretary Cecyll to Sir Henry Neville, March 2, * 559. White. This phrase was euphemistic slang for “to put up with an insult.” Dyce. To submit to any degradation (“II a du feu en la teste. II et tholle7’icke, furious, or couragious; he will cari'ie no coaleil.' Cotgrave’s Fr, and Engl. Diet., sub. “Teste”). “To carry coals, va the sense of tamely putting up an affront, occurs perpetually in our old writers, both serious and comic.” Gifford’s Jonson, vol. ii, p. 169. (In Lyly’s Midas, mention is made of “one of the Cole house,” sig. f; 4, ed. 1592 i. e., one of the drudges about the palace of Midas.)

4.play: SAMPSON : I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.

5.play: GREGORY : Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.
notes: Steevens: colliers.] A very ancient term of abuse. Twelfth Night, III, iv, 130. Any person who would bear to be called a collier was said to carry coals. It afterwards became descriptive of any one who would endure a gibe or flout. So, in Churchyard’s Farewell to the World, 1598: “ He carried coales that could abide no gest.” [/Az/. Halliwell adds instances from Stephens’ Essayes, 1615; Autobiography of Sir John Bramston, p. 42; Wild’s Iter Boreale, 1670, p. 65; Canidia, or the Witches, 1683.

6.play: SAMPSON : I strike quickly, being moved.

7.play: GREGORY : But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

8.play: SAMPSON : A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

9.play: GREGORY : To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:

10.play: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn't away.

11.play: SAMPSON : A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will

12.play: take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.

13.play: GREGORY : That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes

14.play: to the wall.

15.play: SAMPSON : True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,

16.play: are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push

17.play: Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids

18.play: to the wall.

19.play: GREGORY : The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.

20.play: SAMPSON : 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I

21.play: have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the
notes: Coll. (ed. 1): I will be cruel] Coll. (ed. i), “civil” perhaps a misprint for cruel; but Sampson may mean to speak ironically. Del. Irony here in Sampson’s mouth would be out of place. [ Ulr. Coll. (ed. 2), “cruel” the emendation of the (MS.). The misprint of civil for “cruel” is allowed to remain in Greene and Lodge’s “ Looking Glass for London and England” (Dyce’s edit, i, 74), “And play the civil wanton” for cruel wanton.” Dyce (ed. 2), “cruel?” On this word Coll. (ed. 2) has a note, in which he shows his ignorance of our old language. [The foregoing note of Coll. quoted.] The passage in question is, “ Madam, unless you coy it trick and trim, And play the civU wanton ere you yield,” etc.; where “ civil" means grave, sober. The same author in his Never too Late, speaking of the courtesans of Troynovant (i.e., London), tells us that “she that holdeth in her eie most ciuility, hath oft in hir heart most dishonestie, being like the pyrit stone that is fier without and frost within.” See my Account of Greene and his Writings p. 8, ed. 1861.

22.play: maids, and cut off their heads.

23.play: GREGORY : The heads of the maids?

24.play: SAMPSON : Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;

25.play: take it in what sense thou wilt.

26.play: GREGORY : They must take it in sense that feel it.

27.play: SAMPSON : Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and

28.play: 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

29.play: GREGORY : 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou

30.play: hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes
notes: Mai.: poor John] Sta. The fish called hahcy an inferior sort of cod, when dried and salted, was probably the staple fare of servants and the indigent during Lent; and this sorry dish is perpetually ridiculed by the old writers as poor John, [Substantially also Mai. Sing. Huds. Coll. Dyce Cham. Cham. The Gadus merluccius.

Staunton: poor John] Sta. The fish called habley, an inferior sort of cod, when dried and salted, was probably the staple fare of servants and the indigent during Lent; and this sorry dish is perpetually ridiculed by the old writers as poor John, [Substantially also Mai., Sing., Huds., Coll., Dyce, Cham. Cham. The Gadus merluccius.

31.play: two of the house of the Montagues.
notes: Mai.: here comes two] Mai.. The partisans of the Montagues wore a token in their hats to distinguish them from their enemies, the Capulets. Hence, throughout this play, they are known at a distance. This circumstance is mentioned by Gascoigne, in a Devise of a Masque, written for Viscount Montacute, 1575; “ And for a further proofe, he shewed in bys hat Thys token which the Moimtacutes did beare alwaies, for that They covet to be knowne from Capels, where they pass, For ancient grutch whych long ago 'tweene these two houses was.” The disregard of concord is in character. [5’f«^. Huds. Sta. Hal. Clarke, Del. The omission of the nominative is characteristic of the careless familiar talk of servants. Here comes (something) of the house of Montague. Especially [adds Ulr.] as this indefiniteness has a tone of contempt.

Mai.: here comes two] Mai. The partisans of the Montagues wore a token in their hats to distinguish them from their enemies, the Capulets. Hence, throughout this play, they are known at a distance. This circumstance is mentioned by Gascoigne, in a Devise of a Masque, written for Viscount Montacute, 1575; ** And for a further proofe, he shewed in bys hat Thys token which the Montacutes did beare alwaies, for that They covet to be knowne from Capels, where they pass, For ancient grutch whych long ago 'tweene these two houses was.” The disregard of concord is in character. [Steev., Huds., Sta., Hal., Clarke, Del. The omission of the nominative is characteristic of the careless familiar talk of servants. Here comes (something) of the house of Montague. Especially [adds Ulr.] as this indefiniteness has a tone of contempt.

32.play: SAMPSON : My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

33.play: GREGORY : How! turn thy back and run?

35.play: GREGORY : No, marry; I fear thee!

36.play: SAMPSON : Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.

37.play: GREGORY : I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as

39.play: SAMPSON : Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;
notes: Steevens: I will bite my thumb at them] Lodge, in Wits Miserie, &c., 1596: “Behold next I see Contempt marching forth, giving me the fico with his thumbe in his mouth." [^Sing, Knt, Huds, Dyce^ White, Hal, Mal. This mode of quarreling appears to have been common in our author’s time. “ What swearing is there” (says Decker, describing the groups that frequented the walks of St. Paul’s Church), “what shouldering, what justling, what jeering, what byting oj thumbs, to beget quarrels!” The Dead Term, 1608. [^Sing. Corn. Knt. Coll. Huds. White, Dyce, Hal. Clarke. Nakes. The thumb in this action represented a fig, and the whole was equivalent to a fig for you, or the fico. Dags and pistols! To bite his thumb at me! Wear I a sword To see men bite their thumbs? Randolphy Muses' L. Glass. O. Pl. ix, 320. [.Smg, Knt. There can be little doubt, we apprehend, that this mode of insult was originally peculiar to Italy, and was perhaps a mitigated form of the greater insult of making the fig or fico, that is, thrusting out the thumb in a peculiar manner between the fingers. Douce has bestowed much laborious investigation upon this difficult and somewhat worthless subject. The commentators have not distinctly alluded to what appears to us the identity of biting the thumb and the fico; but the passage in Lodge’s “Wits Miserie” clearly shows that the customs were one and the same. Sing. The mode in which this contemptuous action was performed is thus described by Cotgrave, in a passage which has escaped the industry of all the commentators; “ Faire la nique; to mocke by nodding or lifting up the chinne; or more properly, to threaten or defie, by putting the thumbe naile into the mouth, and with a jerke (from the upper teeth) make it to knacke.” [Corn. Huds. Dyce, Sta. Hal. Cham. Clarke. Hunter. A trait of Italian manners. Thus Fuller, in his Abel Redivivus, p. 38, after relating a conversation between Luther and a messenger of Cardinal Cajetan, says, “At this the messenger, after the Italian manner, biting his thumbs, went away.” Sta. This contemptuous action, though obsolete in this country, is still in use both in France and Italy; but Knight is mistaken in supposing it identical with what is giving the fico. Biting the thumb is performed by biting the thumb-nail; or as Cotgrave describes it [as cited by Singer]: The more offensive gesticulation of giving the fico was by thrusting out the thumb between the forefingers, or putting it in the mouth so as to swell out the cheek.
Steevens: I will bite my thumb at them] See above (note at line 12) for detailed explanation and citations regarding the custom, also that it was a mode of Italian insult, akin to giving the fico.

40.play: which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

42.play: ABRAHAM : Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

43.play: SAMPSON : I do bite my thumb, sir.

44.play: ABRAHAM : Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

45.play: SAMPSON : [Aside to GREGORY] Is the law of our side, if I say

48.play: SAMPSON : No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I

52.play: SAMPSON : If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.

55.play: GREGORY : Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.
notes: White: Enter Benvolio] Ulr. It is clear that the words of Gregory, immediately following, refer to Tybalt. Probably the omission of “and Tybalt” is a typographical oversight; “at a distance” is to be referred to Tybalt. At all events, we may be allowed to make changes in such cases where the connection demands them.

Steevens: here comes one] Steev. Gregory may mean Tybalt, who enters immediately after Benvolio, but on a different part of the stage. The eyes of the servant may be directed the way he sees Tybalt coming, and in the mean time Benvolio enters on the opposite side. [Sing., Huds.]

58.play: SAMPSON : Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.
notes: Steevens: thy swashing blow.] Jonson in his Staple of News: “I do confess a swashing blow.” Again in As You Like It: I, iii, 122. To swash seems to have meant to be a bully, to be noisily valiant. Barrett, in his Alvearie, 1580, says that “to swash is to make a noise with swords against tergats.” [Coll. Verp. Huds., Nares. Exactly as we now say dashing; spirited and calculated to surprise. Also [as in this place] violent, overpowering. Knt. Samson and Gregory are described as armed with swords and bucklers. The swashing blow is a blow upon the buckler; the blow accompanied with a noise; and thus a swasher came to be synonymous with a quarrelsome fellow, a braggart. In Henry V, Bardolph, Pistol, and Nym are called by the boy three “swashers.” Holinshed has: “a man may see how many bloody quarrels a brawling swash buckler may pick out of a bottle of hay;” and Fuller, in his “Worthies,” after describing a swaggerer as one that endeavors to make that side to swagger, or weigh down, whereon he engages, tells us that a swash-buckler is so called from swashing or making a noise on bucklers. Del. The “swashing blow” of the Ff. might be justified, at a pinch, as a laughable mistake for the correct phrase, purposely put into the mouth of a servant. Sta. Evidently it here means a smashing, crushing blow. Dyce. A blow that comes down with noise and violence, an overpowering blow. (“To swash (or clash with swords and armour), Chamailler,” Cotgrave’s Fr. and Eng. Diet.). Halliwell. “To fence, to swash with swords, to swagger,” Florio, p. 127. To swash, clango, gladiis concrepo, Coles. Forby has swash, to affect valour, to vapour, or swagger; but these are secondary meanings. When as the fight therefore grew exceeding sharpe and hot, with much slaughter and bloudslied, every one who was more readie to rush upon the thickest of the enemies, whiles on all sides swords swashed and darts flew as thick as haile, lost his life. Ammianus Marcellinus, translated by Holland, 1609.

62.play: Put up your swords; you know not what you do.

65.play: TYBALT : What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
notes: Ulr.: Enter Tybalt] Ulr. Here it is to be understood that Tybalt advances so as to be seen by the spectators.

66.play: Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.

67.play: BENVOLIO : I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,

68.play: Or manage it to part these men with me.

69.play: TYBALT : What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,

70.play: As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:

73.play: Enter, several of both houses, who join the fray; then enter Citizens, with clubs

74.play: First Citizen : Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!
notes: Mal.: Clubs] Mal. It appears from many of our old dramas that it was a common custom, on the breaking out of a fray, to call out Clubs! Clubs to part the combatants. So in Tit. And. II, i, 37. [Note on As You Like It, V, ii, 44.] Knt. The cry of “clubs” is as thoroughly of English origin as the “bite my thumb” is of Italian. Scott has made the cry familiar to us in “The Fortunes of Nigel;” and when the citizens of Verona here raise it, we involuntarily think of the old watch-maker’s hatch-door in Fleet Street and Jin Vin and Tunstall darting off for the affray. “The great long club” as described by Stow, on the necks of the London apprentices, was as characteristic as the flat cap of the same (luarrelsome body, in the days of Elizabeth and James. The use by Sh. of home phrases, in the mouth of foreign characters, was a part of his art. It is the same thing as rendering Sancho’s Spanish proverbs into the corresponding English proverbs, instead of literally translating them. The cry of clubs by the citizens of Verona expressed an idea of popular movement, which could not have been conveyed half so emphatically in a foreign phrase. [ Verp. Huds., IIaz. As we should now say, police. Hunter. This word should probably be so printed as to indicate that the citizen called out, “Clubs,” an English expression used to part combatants. It may still sometimes be heard, and occurs in As You Like V, ii, 44. Sta. Sh., whose wont it is to assimilate the customs of all countries to those of his own, puts the ancient call to arms of the London ’prentices in the mouth of the Veronese citizen. Dyce. Originally, the cry to call forth the London apprentices, who employed their clubs to preserve the public peace: sometimes, however, they used those weapons to raise a disturbance. See Hen. VIII: V, iii. Clarke. This speech seems to be a collection of exclamations uttered by several persons rather than the words of one person.

Nares: bills.] Nares. A kind of pike or halbert formerly carried by the English infantry, and afterwards the usual weapon of watchmen. It is described by Sir Wm. Temple as giving the most ghastly wounds, which may be imagined by the figures of bills delineated in Steevens’s Shakespeare, vol. ii, p. 316, ed. 1778. Johnson tells us that these weapons were carried by the watchmen of Lichfield in 1778.

Fairholt: bills.] Fairholt. These long-popular weapons of the foot-soldier were constructed to thrust at mounted men, or cut and damage their horse-furniture. Sometimes they were provided with a side-hook to seize a bridle. [Dyce.

Nares: partisans.] Nares. Old French, a kind of pike or halbert. [Sing. Fairholt. It may be described as a sharp two-edged sword placed on the summit of a staff for the defence of foot-soldiers against cavalry. [Dyce.

75.play: Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!

76.play: Enter CAPULET in his gown, and LADY CAPULET
notes: Del: in his gown.] Del. Intimating that he has been disturbed in his night’s rest.

77.play: CAPULET : What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!
notes: Sing.: long sword.] Sing. This was the weapon used in active warfare; a lighter, shorter, and less desperate weapon was worn for ornament, to which we have other allusions: “No sword worn but one to dance with.” [Clarke,

78.play: LADY CAPULET : A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

79.play: CAPULET : My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,

80.play: And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

82.play: MONTAGUE : Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.

83.play: LADY MONTAGUE : Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.
notes: Sta.: Seek a foe.] Sta. (Q1), which is peculiarly interesting from its presenting us with the poet’s first projection of a play, he subsequently expanded and elaborated with much care and skill, and is valuable too, in helping us to correct many typographical errors, and to supply some lines omitted perhaps by negligence in the later editions, makes short work of this scene,

85.play: PRINCE : Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
notes: Ulr.: Profaners] Ulr. This verse, and indeed the whole speech of the Prince, reminds one of the bombastic, overstrained diction of Marlowe, whom Sh. at first, e. g. in Titus And., took for a model.

87.play: Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,

88.play: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage

89.play: With purple fountains issuing from your veins,

90.play: On pain of torture, from those bloody hands

91.play: Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,
notes: Steevens: mistemper’d.] Steev. Angry. So in King John, “This inundation of mistemper’d humor.” {Sing, Clarke, Del. With the secondary meaning, perverted or tempered to misfortune.

92.play: And hear the sentence of your moved prince.

93.play: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,

94.play: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,

95.play: Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,

notes: Del.: ancient citizens.] Del. Not of necessity those citizens who are old in years, but those who have anciently settled there and become accustomed to peace and order.

97.play: To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
notes: Walker: grave beseeming.] Walker {*Crit.* vol. I, p. 24) “grave-beseeming;” i.e. beseeming gravity, σεμνότροπος (Compare Hamlet IV, vii: for youth no less becomes The light and careless livery that it wears, Than settled age his sables, and his weeds. Importing health and graveness.”) And so perhaps Spenser F. Q. vi, xxxvi: — he toward them did pace With staged steps and grave-beseeming grace though here I am not quite certain.

98.play: Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:
notes: Del.: cankered with peace] Del. Rust, through long years of peace, has eaten into the partisans, just as hate has into the hearts of the rival factions.

99.play: If ever you disturb our streets again,

100.play: Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.

101.play: For this time, all the rest depart away:

102.play: You Capulet; shall go along with me:

103.play: And, Montague, come you this afternoon,

104.play: To know our further pleasure in this case,

105.play: To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.
notes: Mal.: To old Free-town] Mal. This name the poet found in the Tragicall History of Romeus and Juliet, 1562. It is there said to be the castle of the Capulets. [Sw^. White. This name is but a translation of Villa Franca of the old Italian story.

Coleridge: Place of the Prince's Speech] Coleridge (Lit. Rem. vol. II, p. 151, ed. 1836). With his accustomed judgment, Shakespeare has begun by placing before us a lively picture of all the impulses of the play; and as nature ever presents two sides, one for Heraclitus and one for Democritus, he has, by way of prelude, shown the laughable absurdity of the evil by the contagion of it reaching the servants, who have so little to do with it, but who are under the necessity of letting the superfluity of sensorial power fly off through the escape-valve of wit-combats, and of quarreling with weapons of a sharper edge, all in humble imitation of their masters. Yet there is a sort of unhi red fidelity, an ourishness about all this, that makes it rest pleasant on one’s feelings. All the first scene, down to the conclusion of the Prince’s speech, is a motley dance of all ranks and ages to one tune, as if the horn of Huon had been playing behind the scenes. Illuds.

106.play: Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.

107.play: Exeunt all but MONTAGUE, LADY MONTAGUE, and BENVOLIO

108.play: MONTAGUE : Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?

109.play: Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

110.play: BENVOLIO : Here were the servants of your adversary,

111.play: And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:

112.play: I drew to part them: in the instant came

113.play: The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,

114.play: Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,

115.play: He swung about his head and cut the winds,

116.play: Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:

117.play: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,

118.play: Came more and more and fought on part and part,

119.play: Till the prince came, who parted either part.

120.play: LADY MONTAGUE : O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?

121.play: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

122.play: BENVOLIO : Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun
notes: Coll.: Which then, etc.] Coll. The plain meaning seems to be, that Benvolio, like Romeo, was indisposed for society, and sought to be most, where most people were not to be found, being one too many, even when by himself. [ Verp.

123.play: Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,

124.play: A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;

125.play: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore

126.play: That westward rooteth from the city's side,

127.play: So early walking did I see your son:

128.play: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me

129.play: And stole into the covert of the wood:

130.play: I, measuring his affections by my own,

131.play: That most are busied when they're most alone,

132.play: Pursued my humour not pursuing his,
notes: Del.: Which then, etc.] Del. Benvolio measured Romeo’s inclinations by his own, which at that time sought for some solitary spot where other people could not be found, because he himself, with his own wearisome /, appeared to be too much company, and followed his own humour without pursuing Romeo’s.

Ulr.: Which then, etc.] Ulr. Benvolio means to say that he was in a melancholy state similar to Romeo’s, and hence appreciated the mood of the latter by his own, which then most sought there where mostly nothing is to be found, i.e. which sought the most comfort, the most help, in solitude, where it is not to be found. This turning to solitude, he adds, was so strong in him that he was too much for himself, for his own weary self (for one person), “ therefore he had pursued his humour,” etc. Collier 115 with true judgment restored the above reading, but to his explanation of this second “most,” as meaning “most people,” I cannot assent.
Coll.: humour] Coll. In all the Qq and Ff, excepting Q1, “humour” is misprinted honour, but the error is set right by the (MS).

133.play: And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.

134.play: MONTAGUE : Many a morning hath he there been seen,

135.play: With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.

136.play: Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
notes: Del.: sighs] Del. a frequent image in Sh.: “or with our sighs will breathe the welkin dim.” Tit. And. III, i.

137.play: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun

138.play: Should in the furthest east begin to draw

139.play: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,

140.play: Away from the light steals home my heavy son,
notes: Del.: heavy] Del. The playing upon the words “light” as a noun, and “light” as an adjective, is very common in Sh.

141.play: And private in his chamber pens himself,

142.play: Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out

143.play: And makes himself an artificial night:

144.play: Black and portentous must this humour prove,

145.play: Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

146.play: BENVOLIO : My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

147.play: MONTAGUE : I neither know it nor can learn of him.

148.play: BENVOLIO : Have you importuned him by any means?

149.play: MONTAGUE : Both by myself and many other friends:

150.play: But he, his own affections' counsellor,

151.play: Is to himself--I will not say how true--

152.play: But to himself so secret and so close,

153.play: So far from sounding and discovery,

154.play: As is the bud bit with an envious worm,

155.play: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,

156.play: Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
notes: Theobald: sun.] Theobald. When we come to consider that there is some power else besides balmy air that brings forth and makes the tiny buds spread themselves, I do not think it improbable that the poet wrote, ‘or dedicate his beauty to the sun,’ or, according to the more obsolete spelling, sunne, which brings it nearer to the traces of the corrupted text. [Smg. Knt. Corn. Ilaz, Ktly. Hal.

Johnson: sun.] Johnson. I cannot but suspect that some lines are lost which connected this simile more closely with the foregoing speech; these lines, if such there were, lamented the danger that Romeo will die of his melancholy before his virtues or abilities were known to the world.
Malone: sun.] Malone. This sense is supported by Daniel’s Sonnets, 1594, and by analogous lines in Shakespeare’s own Sonnets and Venus and Adonis (see debate in commentary).

157.play: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.

158.play: We would as willingly give cure as know.

notes: Dyce: Enter Romeo] Dyce. The old edd. mark his entrance some lines earlier, just as previously, in the present scene, they make Abraham and Balthasar, and also Benvolio, enter too soon, and only because they followed the prompter’s book, which had the entrances so set down to show that the performers were to be in readiness to appear on the stage. Again, in Act II, sc. iii, according to the old edd., Romeo enters while the Friar has yet several lines of his soliloquy to utter. [Vide ‘Remarks,’ &c., p. 147.] COLEKIDGE (Lit. Rem., vol. ii, p. 152, ed. 1836): If we are right, from internal evidence, in pronouncing this one of Sh.’s early dramas, it affords a strong instance of the fineness of his insight into the nature of the passions that Romeo is already love-bewildered.... [Verp. Huds. White (vol. i, p. ccxxx): see text.]

160.play: BENVOLIO : See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;

161.play: I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.
notes: Staunton: I am in love] Sta. In the old poem the hero is first introduced to us, as In the play, the victim to an unrequited passion....

162.play: MONTAGUE : I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,

163.play: To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.

166.play: ROMEO : Is the day so young?

168.play: ROMEO : Ay me! sad hours seem long.

169.play: Was that my father that went hence so fast?

170.play: BENVOLIO : It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

171.play: ROMEO : Not having that, which, having, makes them short.

175.play: ROMEO : Out of her favour, where I am in love.

176.play: BENVOLIO : Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,

177.play: Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

178.play: ROMEO : Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,

179.play: Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!
notes: Steevens: pathways] Steev. Romeo laments that love, though blind, should discover pathways to his will, and yet cannot avail himself of them; should perceive the road which he is forbidden to take. [Huds.

Mal.: pathways] Mal. Benvolio has lamented that the god of love, who appears so gentle, should be a tyrant. It is no less to be lamented, adds Romeo, that the blind god should yet be able to direct his arrows at those whom he wishes to hit,—that he should wound whomever he wills or desires to wound. [Mal. Steev. (see also Daniel and Petrarch for conventions).
Sing.: pathways] Sing. That is, should blindly and recklessly think he can surmount all obstacles to his will. [Huds.

Ulr.: pathways] Ulr. Romeo wishes to say, “O that Love, in spite of his veiled countenance (in spite of the bandages over his eyes), yet without eyes should find side- paths (all kinds of fine means) to accomplish his will! i.e. that Love steals over us and holds us fast, however much we would gladly escape or be free.”
Sta.: pathways] Sta. Q1 may help us to the true reading, which very probably was "set pathways to our will;" in other words, "make us walk in any direction he chooses to appoint."

Clarke: pathways] Clarke. This sentence comprises double meaning, and signifies not only "Alas, that the blind god should be able to shoot so surely!" but also "Alas, that love, notwithstanding its muffled sight, should be able, blindfold, to find its way to its object!"

180.play: Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?

181.play: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.

182.play: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.

183.play: Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
notes: Farmer: O brawling love] Farmer. Every sonneteer characterized Love by contrarieties.... [See note for full citations of Watson, Turberville, "Romaunt of the Rose," Petrarch, Wyatt, etc.]

184.play: O any thing, of nothing first create!
notes: Knt.: created] Knt. [create] introduces improperly a couplet amidst the blank verse.

187.play: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,

189.play: Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!

190.play: This love feel I, that feel no love in this.

192.play: BENVOLIO : No, coz, I rather weep.

194.play: BENVOLIO : At thy good heart's oppression.

195.play: ROMEO : Why, such is love's transgression.
notes: Collier (ed. 2): love’s transgression] The line in QqFf is four syllables short of the measure required by the corresponding lines above. We have, therefore, not the slightest hesitation in inserting "Benvolio" as we find it in the (MS.), and as we may be almost sure it was originally written. Dyce (ed. 2): Since printing the text of this play, I almost regret that I did not retain the usual arrangement. The passage, however, may be right as it stands, for our early dramatists sometimes introduce short rhyming lines in the midst of blank-verse dialogues, as in Love’s Labour’s Lost, I, i, 126, 127. Ktly. I make this insertion, “gentle cousin,” with confidence, for this is the only speech in this play beginning with a short line not complementary to the end of a preceding speech. In our poet’s plays of this period, speeches never began with a short line, unless when complementary, and at no time was the second line of a couplet short. Lower down (I, v, 63), we have “Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone,” where Q omits all but “let him alone.”

196.play: Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,

197.play: Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest

198.play: With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown

199.play: Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
notes: Del.: too much] Del. This is to be taken substantively as a compound word.

200.play: Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;

201.play: Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;
notes: Johnson: Being purged] Johnson. Sh. may mean being purged of smoke, which is, perhaps, a meaning never given to the word in any other place. I would rather read, “Being urg'd”—being excited and enforced. To urge the fire is a technical term. [Sing. (ed. i), Dyce (ed. 2). Reed. Dr Akenside, in his Hymn to Cheerfulness, has the same expression: “Haste, light the tapers, urge the fire.” Again, in Chapman’s version of the 21st Iliad: “And as a caldron, under put with store of fire 'Bavins of sere wood urging it,’ &c. {Sing. Del. Purged must be taken in connection with the preceding: when Love has been purified from the fume of sighs [see l. 126] it becomes a fire, &c. Thus understood, Johnson’s emendation is unnecessary. Huds. Johnson’s change is a good one, if any were needed. Of course purged is purified. Coll. [Notes and Emend, p. 382]. Everybody is aware how a fire sometimes sparkles in the eyes of those who blow it with their breath: the smoke is first “made” by the gentle “fume of sighs,” and then caused to sparkle by being violently by the lover’s breath. Sta. pronounces Johnson’s suggestion “one not without reason,” and Collier’s (MS.) as equally plausible. White. Surely the correctors must have failed to see the allusion to the passage in the Gospels (Matt, iii, 12), “whose fan is in his hand, and he will thoroughly purge his floor.” Sh. remembered the “fan,” and thought of the winnowing that he had seen at Stratford....

202.play: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:
notes: Johnson: Being vex’d] Johnson. As this line stands single, it is likely that the foregoing, or following line, that rhymed to it is lost. [Ktly.

203.play: What is it else? a madness most discreet,

204.play: A choking gall and a preserving sweet.
notes: Ulr.: preserving] Ulr. Sh., in his careless diction, ever delighting in popular phrases, continually used the active and passive participles, each for the other, as can be shown by many passages. He here intentionally uses “preserving” in the place of “preserved,” merely for the sake of a play upon words, and to bring out the contrast with “choking gall.” Love may be compared to a preserved sweet because, although againjt our will, it is kept and cherished.

206.play: BENVOLIO : Soft! I will go along;

207.play: An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

208.play: ROMEO : Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;

209.play: This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

210.play: BENVOLIO : Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

211.play: ROMEO : What, shall I groan and tell thee?

notes: Johnson: sadness] Johnson. That is, tell me gravely; tell me in seriousness. [Sing.
Ktly.: tell me who] Ktly. The words “she is you love” seem evidently to have been lost; and the repetition is very agreeable. Moreover, in this play speeches do not thus end with a short line.

214.play: ROMEO : Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:

215.play: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!
notes: Ulr.: make his will] Ulr. The sense is: A sick man, of his own accord, makes his last will in seriousness (he need not be bidden to do it “in seriousness”), and hence the word, in the mere sense of “seriousness,” is ill used to one who is in so bad a state as I am. I cannot accept the reading of Q1, as the following line appears to fit it less, or rather the sense of the whole passage comes out far more clearly in the reading of the other editions.

216.play: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

217.play: BENVOLIO : I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.

218.play: ROMEO : A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.

219.play: BENVOLIO : A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

220.play: ROMEO : Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit

221.play: With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;

222.play: And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,

223.play: From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
notes: Steevens: strong proof] Steev. As this play was written in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, I cannot help regarding these speeches of Romeo as an oblique compliment to her majesty, who was not liable to be displeased at hearing her chastity praised after she was suspected to have lost it, or her beauty commended in the 67th year of her age, though she never possessed any when she was young. Her declaration that she would continue unmarried increases the probability of the present supposition. [Iiar. Sing.

224.play: She will not stay the siege of loving terms,

225.play: Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,

226.play: Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:

227.play: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,

228.play: That when she dies with beauty dies her store.
notes: Johnson: with beauty dies] Johnson. She is rich, says Romeo, in beauty; and only poor in being subject to the lot of humanity, that her store, or riches, can be destroyed by death, who shall, by the same blow, put an end to beauty. [Haz. Steev. Theobald’s alteration may be countenanced by the following passage in Swetnam Arraign’d, a comedy, 1620: “Nature now shall boast no more of the riches of her store; Since, in this her chiefest prize, all the stock of beauty dies.” Again, in Shakespeare’s 14th Sonnet; “Thy end is truth’s and beauty’s doom and date.” Again, in Massinger’s Virgin-Martyr: — with her dies The abstract of all sweetness that's in woman.” [Hal. Mason. Romeo means to say that she is poor because she leaves no part of her store behind her, as with her all beauty will die. (ed. i), Huds. Hal. Mal.. She is rich in beauty; and poor, in this circumstance alone, that with her beauty will expire. Her store of wealth, which the poet has already said was the fairness of her person, will not be transmitted to posterity, inasmuch as she will “lead her graces to the grave and leave the world no copy.” [Hal. Mal. also cites Shakespeare’s 3d Sonnet and Venus and Adonis, 757,

229.play: BENVOLIO : Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

230.play: ROMEO : She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,

231.play: For beauty starved with her severity
notes: Sing.: starved] Sing. (ed. 2). All the old copies have starv'd, which has been here and elsewhere changed to starv'd without reason. The poet has shown that he wrote starve by making it rhyme to deserve in Cor. II, iii; and the confined meaning of starve in its modern acceptation renders the preservation of the archaic form desirable if not necessary....

232.play: Cuts beauty off from all posterity.

233.play: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
notes: Mal.: wisely too fair] Mal. There is in her too much sanctimonious wisdom united with beauty, which induces her to continue chaste with the hopes of attaining heavenly bliss, [Haz. (substantially).

Ulr.: wisely too fair] Ulr. Schlegel, I think, translates it incorrectly. SCHLEGEL, Sie ist zu schön und weis’, um Heil zu erben, Weil sie, mit Weisheit schön, mich zwingt zu sterben. Del. The excess of her beauty does not accord with the excess of her wisdom, she ought not to try to win heavenly bliss while burdening herself with sin by plunging Romeo into despair.

234.play: To merit bliss by making me despair:

235.play: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow

236.play: Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

237.play: BENVOLIO : Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

238.play: ROMEO : O, teach me how I should forget to think.

239.play: BENVOLIO : By giving liberty unto thine eyes;

242.play: To call hers exquisite, in question more:
notes: Heath: To call hers, exquisite] Heath. That is, to call hers, which is exquisite, the more into my remembrance and contemplation. It is in this sense, and not in that of doubt or dispute, that the word question is here used. [Huds. Mal. More into talk; to make her unparalleled beauty more the subject of thought and conversation. Question means conversation. So in the Rape of Lucrece: “And after supper long he questioned With modest Lucrece.” And in many passages in our author’s plays. [Sing. and Huds. subs. Hal. Sta. Ktly. To “call in question,” in Sh. always means, to express a doubt or Question is examine, a word just used.

243.play: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows
notes: These happy masks] Stekv. I. e.^ the masks worn by female spectators of the play. (ed. l), probably, unless’’ Malone be right. Huds. Mal. These happy masks, I believe, means no more than the happy masks. Such is Tyrwhitt’s opinion. Knt. It seems scarcely necessary to limit the use of masks to the female spectators of the play. In the Two Gentlemen of Verona we have the “ sun-expelling mask.” In Love’s Labour’s Lost the ladies wear masks in the first interview between the king and the princess : “ Now fair befall your mask,” says Biron to Rosaline. Del. Such masks as the ladies of Sh.’s time were wont to wear when they went out in the street. Dyce (ed. 2) [in a note on Mea. for Mca. II, iv, 79]. As to “these black tnasksT Tyrwhitt, in his earlier days, conjectured that Sli. alluded to “ the masks of the audience when the play was acted at court;” but he afterwards repudiated that most extravagant conjecture. “ My notion at present,” he says, “ is that the phrase, these black masksy signifies nothing more than black viasksy according to an old idiom of our language, by which the demonstrative pronoun is put for the ])repositive arti- cle.” So we have in the present play [Mea. for Mea.], IV, i, 59: “volumes of report Run with these fiilse and most contrarious quests.” And compare Webster, The Duchess of Malfiy V, ii “We that are great women of pleasure use to cut off These uncertain wishes and unquiet longings And in an instant join the sweet delight And the pretty excuse together.” (I cannot but feel surprised that Tyrwhitt’s discarded conjecture, about these masui meaning the masks of the audience, should have been brought forward by Halliwell as a probal)le one, and that he should conceive it to be supported by a passage (to which he only refers) at the conclusion of Fletcher’s Beggar's Bush, where Higgen, speaking the epiloguey says to the “ladies,” “If you be pleas’d, look cheerJy, throw your eyes Out at your masks.”) Clarke. The masks usually worn, and happy in being privileged to touch the sweet countenances beneath, “ These” is here used to instance a general obser- vation.

244.play: Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;
notes: Being black put us] White. The old copies, ^'puts us in mind,” and, I have little doubt, correctly ; for, aside from other reasons for reading ^^putsf I am inclined to think that Sh. and his contemporaries regarded “ being black” and not “ masks” as the nominative to “ put.” I do not, however, feel sufficiently assured of the point to change the received text

245.play: He that is strucken blind cannot forget

246.play: The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:

247.play: Show me a mistress that is passing fair,

248.play: What doth her beauty serve, but as a note

249.play: Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?

250.play: Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

251.play: BENVOLIO : I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

notes: [Corn. Sta. The meaning of this somewhat complex passage seems to be: She is rich in the possession of unequalled beauty, but poor, because having devoted herself to chastity, when she dies her wealth, that is beauty, dies with her. The same conceit occurs repeatedly in Shakespeare’s poems; see cited Sonnets and examples. White. Romeo means to say that his mistress is only poor in that, at her death, her store — i. e. the beauty that she is rich in — will die with her, and that so her chief wealth is a possession that she cannot bequeath. Dyce (ed. 2). “The sense required, as is clear from Benvolio’s rejoinder, and even from Malone’s note, in which he defends the old reading, is that her beauty dies with her; but this sense cannot be squeezed out of the old text; therefore Theobald’s conjecture is necessary.” Lettsom. Kkightley. The plain meaning of this is that beauty was “her store;” she had nothing but it; poor praise indeed from a lover. I would read with Theobald. ... The same idea is expressed in the poet’s first and following Sonnets: in Venus and Adonis we have, “For he being dead, with him is beauty slain.” See also Twelfth Night, I, v.

1.play: Enter CAPULET, PARIS, and Servant

2.play: CAPULET : But Montague is bound as well as I,

3.play: In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think,

4.play: For men so old as we to keep the peace.

5.play: PARIS : Of honourable reckoning are you both;

6.play: And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.

7.play: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

8.play: CAPULET : But saying o'er what I have said before:

9.play: My child is yet a stranger in the world;

10.play: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years,
notes: White (Introd. p. 34): fourteen years] White (Introd. p. 34). In Brooke’s poem Capulet says, “ Scarse saw she yet full xvi yeres.” This is the reading of the ed. 1562, according to Collier’s reprint. It is possible that in one of the two other edd., 1582 and 1587, one of which Sh. would have been likelier to use than the earliest impression, there may have been the very easy misprint, by transposition, “ xiv yeres.” On such points as this he followed closely the text in hand of the novelists and chroniclers whose works he dramatized; and the probability of some such error is the greater, from the fact that in Paynter’s prose tale the father gives Juliet yet two years more, saying, “ she is not yet altayned to the age of xviii yeares.” But, if no such error were made, it would seem as if Sh. reduced Juliet’s age to the very lowest point at which girls are marriageable in England, that he might accommodate it to the garrulous Nurse’s characteristic reference to the earthquake.
CiiAM: The probability is, that “ fourteen” was a slip of the pen or the press.

11.play: Let two more summers wither in their pride,

12.play: Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

13.play: PARIS : Younger than she are happy mothers made.
notes: Se3nnour conj.: happy\ married Se3nnour conj.

14.play: CAPULET : And too soon marr'd are those so early made.
notes: Steev.: made] Steev. Puttenham, Arte, 1589, uses this expression, which seems to be proverbial, as an instance of a figure which he calls the Rebound: “The maid that soon married is, soon marred is.” The jingle between marr’d and made is likewise frequent among the old writers. So Sidney: “Oh I he is marr’d, that is for others made I” Spenser uses it very often. [Sing. lluds, Hal. Sing. (ed. 2) to the foregoing citations adds : “You’re to be marred or marryed, as they say. To-day or to-morrow, to-morrow or to-day.”—Flecknoe’s Epigrams, p. 61.

White: made] White. In printing the compositor seems to have been misled by the existence of a jingling adage similar to that in All’s Well, and perhaps by “made” at the end of the previous line. The quibble here (All’s Well, II, iii, 315) is just worth noticing because it depends upon the same sound of the a in both words, and the full pronunciation of the participial ed in both when the play was written. The contraction of the last, for rhyme’s sake, would not destroy the little joke for an ear accustomed to the full sound of both words.

DycE: made] DycE. Sh. has this jingle several times. So in this present play, II, iv, 103, and in Macbeth II, iii, 28; and, as Paris has used the word “made” it appears to me most natural that Capulet, in his rejoinder, should use “ made” also.

15.play: The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she,
notes: DEL.: sv/allow’d] DEL. To complete the verse the majority of edd. put the definite article before earth, and erroneously read sivallow’d (dissyllable) instead of svalloived (trisyllable).
DycE: sv/allow’d] DycE. It is not to be made verse by retaining the e in the participle.
White, Clarke.: sv/allow’d] White, Clarke. This conveys the idea that Capulet had other children who died early.

16.play: She is the hopeful lady of my earth:
notes: Steev.: lady of my earth] Steev. A Gallicism: Fille de terre is the French phrase for an heiress.
Knt. Huds. Sta, WhitEy Dyce (ed. i), Huds. M. Mason.: lady of my earth] Knt. Huds. Sta, WhitEy Dyce (ed. i), Huds. M. Mason. Here earth means corporal part.
Mal.: lady of my earth] Mal. Again in this play, II, i, 2. Again, in Sh.’s 146th Sonnet: “Poor soul, the centre of my sinful earth.”

Knt. Sta. Ulr.: lady of my earth] Knt. Sta. Ulr. That is, she is the hopeful mistress of my world, my life; not, as Stcevens has it, of my landed estate, nor as Knight, with Mason and Malone, thinks, of my “ body.”
Dyce (ed. 2): lady of my earth] Dyce (ed. 2). Lettsom suspects that the close of this line is corrupt.

Ktly.: lady of my earth] Ktly. Here a rime is lost in consequence of the first line being in the printer’s mind. There can be little question, I should think, that the original word was not “earth” but fee, feud, fief, landed property, as in Knight's fee, in law, &c., with which alone “lady” accords.
Clarke.: lady of my earth] Clarke. It is most likely that Capulet intends to include the sense of “ she is my sole surviving offspring, in whom I have centred all my hopes.”

17.play: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart,

18.play: My will to her consent is but a part;
notes: Steev.: her consent] Steev. To, in this instance, signifies in comparison with, in proportion to.

Sing. (ed. l), Knt. Del.: her consent] Sing. (ed. l), Knt. Del. This is hardly as Steevens explains it, but it is simply dependent upon “a part”—my will is only a part of her consent, belongs to her consent. The two succeeding verses more fully explain this meaning.

19.play: An she agree, within her scope of choice

20.play: Lies my consent and fair according voice.

21.play: This night I hold an old accustom'd feast,
notes: S. Walker (‘Oll.’ vol. I, p. 38): old accustomed] S. Walker (‘Oll.’ vol. I, p. 38) cites these words as one of his examples under Auld. H. Passages of Sh. in which a compound epithet or participle (or a double substantive) has been resolved into two simple epithets or an adverb and an epithet, &c.

Knt.: feast] Knt. In Romeus and Juliet the season of Capulet’s feast is winter: “The wery winter’s nightes restore the Christmas games, And now the season doth invite to banquet townisli dames. And fyrst in Capels house, the chiefe of all the kyn Sparth for no cost, the wonted use of banquets to begyn.” Sh. had, perhaps, this in his mind when, at the ball, old Capulet cries out, “And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.” But in every other instance the season is unquestionably summer. “ The day is hot,” says Benvolio. The Friar is up in his garden “ ere the sun advance his burning eye.” Juliet hears the nightingale sing from the pomegranate tree. During the whole course of the poem the action appears to move under the “ vaulty heaven” of Italy.

Sta.: feast] Sta. [thus continues Knt.'s quotation from Romeus and Jul.]: “No lady fayre or fowle was in Verona towne, No knight or gentleman of high or lowe renowne; But Capllet himselfe hath byd unto his feast, Or by his name in paper sent, appoynted as a geast.”

22.play: Whereto I have invited many a guest,

23.play: Such as I love; and you, among the store,

24.play: One more, most welcome, makes my number more.

25.play: At my poor house look to behold this night
notes: Wars.: dark heaven light] Wars. This nonsense should be reformed thus: “dark even light,” i.e., When the evening is dark and without stars, these earthly stars supply their place and light it up.
Knt. M. Mason.: dark heaven light] Knt. M. Mason. I propose, “dark, heaven's light,” i.e. earthly stars that outshine the stars of heaven and make them appear dark by their own superior brightness.
Sing. (ed. 2): dark heaven light] Sing. (ed. 2), “ an ingenious emendation.”

Knt.: dark heaven light] Knt. It appears unnecessary to alter the original reading, and especially as passages in the masquerade scene would seem to indicate that the banqueting room opened into a garden, as “ Her beauty hangs upon the cheek of night."

Sta.: dark heaven light] Sta. a better reason for abiding by the original text is to consider that the “ dark heaven” in Sh.’s mind was most probably the Heaven of the stage, hung, as was the custom during the performance of tragedy, with black.
Clarke.: dark heaven light] Clarke. As poetical hyperbole may it not bear the excellent sense of “ mortal ladies, brilliant as stars that make night as bright as day?’

26.play: Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:

27.play: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
notes: Johnson.: lusty young men] Johnson. To say, and to say in pompous words, that a young man shall feel as much in an assembly of beauties as young men feel in the month of April is surely to waste sound upon a very poor sentiment. I read “ lusty yeomen." You shall feel, from the sight and conversation of these ladies, such hopes of happiness and such pleasure, as the farmer receives from the spring, when the plenty of the year begins, and the prospect of the harvest fills him with delight.

Ritson.: lusty young men] Ritson. Young men are yeomen. In A Lytell Geste of Robyn Ilode, printed by Wynken de Worde, where “yonge men" occurs four times, it is in each instance yeomen in Copland’s edition printed not many years after. See also Spel-ean’s Glossary, voce JUNIORES. It is no less singular, that in a subsequent act of this very play the old copies should, in two places, read “young trees" and “young tree'' instead of "yew-trees" and "yew-tree."

Steev.: lusty young men] Steev. To tell Paris that he should feel the same sort of pleasure in an assembly of beauties which young folk feel in that season when they are most gay and amorous, was surely as much as the old man ought to say:—ubi subdita flamma medullis, Vere magis (quia vere calor redit ossibus).”—Virg. Geor, iii, 271-a.
Mal.: lusty young men] Mal. Sh.’s 98th Sonnet may also confirm the reading of the text: “When proud-pied April dressed in all his trim Hath put a spirit of youth in every thing.”
Sing. Coll. Huds.: lusty young men] Sing. Coll. Costard calls for it in Love’s L. L., Ill, i, 74.
Cotgrave: lusty young men] Cotgrave translates Franc-gontier, a good rich yeoman; substantial yonker! He also renders “ Vergaland, a lustie yonker,"

Knt.: lusty young men] Knt. The spirit of Italian poetry was upon Sh. when he wrote these lines; and he thought not of the lusty yeomen in his fields, “ While the ploughman near at hand Whistles o’er the furrow'd land," but of such gay groups as Boccaccio has painted, who “ Sat down in the high grass and in the shade Of many a tree sun-proof.” Sh. has, indeed, explained his own idea of “ well -apparelled April” in his 98th Sonnet. Douce has well observed, that in this passage Sh. might “have had in view the decorations which accompany the above month in some of the manuscript and printed calendars, where the young folks are represented as sitting together on the grass; the men ornamenting the girls with chaplets of flowers.”
Huds.: lusty young men] Huds. What feelings the young are apt to have in the spring can hardly need explaining to those who remember their youth.

Coll. (ed. 2): lusty young men] Coll. (ed. 2). Surely we need not, with Ritson, speculate upon emendation where none is required, and there is no need for altering “ young men” to yeomen, though yeomen may be “ young men,” or “ young men” yeomen,

28.play: When well-apparell'd April on the heel

29.play: Of limping winter treads, even such delight

30.play: Among fresh female buds shall you this night

31.play: Inherit at my house; hear all, all see,
notes: Mal.: inherit] Mal. That is, to possess,

32.play: And like her most whose merit most shall be:

33.play: Which on more view, of many mine being one

34.play: May stand in number, though in reckoning none,
notes: Johnson.: Which on more view, etc.] Johnson. This line I do not understand. The old folio gives no help. I can offer nothing better than Within your view.

Mal.: Which on more view, etc.] Mal. There is here an allusion to an old proverbial expression, that one is no number. So in Decker’s Honest Whore, Part II: “ to fall to one ... is to fall to none, For one no number is.” In Sh.’s 136th Sonnet: “Among a number one is reckon'd none"

M. Mason.: Which on more view, etc.] M. Mason. This passage will not be rendered intelligible by Steevens’s conj., which is neither sense nor English. The old folio leads us to the right reading, which I should suppose to have been thus: “ Whilst on more view of many,” &c. With this alteration the sense is clear, and the deviation from the folio very trifling.

Sing. (ed. i): Which on more view, etc.] Sing. (ed. i). Hear all, see all, and like her most who has the most merit; her, which, after attentively regarding the many, my daughter being one, may stand unique in merit, though she may be reckoned nothing, or held in no estimation.
Huds.: Which on more view, etc.] Huds. Which is here used for who, a substitution frequent in Sh., as in all the writers of his time.

Ulr.: Which on more view, etc.] Ulr. This explanation [of Delius’] I find as difficult to understand as the words themselves. Under these circumstances I have turned back to the reading of Q1, holding the readings of the other copies for misprints or compositors’ sophistications, and I have allowed myself to introduce an emendation into the text, which, in my opinion, gives a perfectly clear sense, and can hardly be termed a change of the text, as it consists only in transposing the first two words. Such a transposition seems always justifiable where the sense requires it, as misprints of this kind, in the very negligent printing of all the old edd., are very numerous.

Badham [Cam. Essays, 1856]: Which on more view, etc.] Badham [Cam. Essays, 1856]. The cause of all this confusion is, that the reading of Q1, being unintelligible, was altered in the subsequent Qq, and that alteration was adopted by the folio. The faulty word was left untouched, and the sound parts were corrupted by the editor of Q2 who did not see that the right reading was, “ such amongst few.”
Sta.: Which on more view, etc.] Sta. Neither reading [of Qq. nor Ff.] affords a clear sense.
Dyce (ed. i): Which on more view, etc.] Dyce (ed. i). The later edd. are not more intelligible than Q1.

White: Which on more view, etc.] White. The passage is obscure, elliptical, and debased by a poor conceit; but, remembering that one used to be regarded as no number, it seems to mean. Such (i.e., so high in merit) my daughter may appear; and being one (of those so distinguished) may stand, in number, one, though, in reckoning, nothing.

Ktly.: Which on more view, etc.] Ktly. I should feel inclined to read, “ Such as on view.” By “ more” must bo meant more extensive. The aposiopesis, so suited to the hasty, impetuous character of the speaker, makes all clear.

Clarke.: Which on more view, etc.] Clarke. “My daughter being one among many such [‘earth-treading stars’ and ‘fresh female buds,’ as I have described, and whom you will see there], she may stand in the number of them, though she may not be counted by you as ‘her whose merit most shall be.’”
Sta.: [To Serv.] Sta. Dyce (ed. 2),

38.play: Through fair Verona; find those persons out
notes: Mal.: [Gives....] Mal. Omitted in Qq Ff, Cambr.

39.play: Whose names are written there, and to them say,
notes: Rowe: written here ? //] Rowe, written lere ! It Dyce, Cambr. written. Here it QqF1F1. written. Jleere it F2. written. Heert it written here! [turns and twists the notes about.] Here [tapping his head] it Nicholson conj.

40.play: My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.

notes: out] out persons Q1.

42.play: Servant : Find them out whose names are written here! It is

43.play: written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his

44.play: yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with
notes: out] out, Q1.

45.play: his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am

46.play: sent to find those persons whose names are here

47.play: person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.

49.play: BENVOLIO : Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning,

50.play: One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish;
notes: Steev.: plantain leaf] Steev. This was a blood-stauncher, and was formerly applied to green wounds. The same thought occurs in Albumazar: “Bring a fresh plantain leaf. I’ve broke my shin.”
Coll. Verp.: plantain leaf] Coll. Verp. We still say, in cant language, to crack a bottle.

Knt.: plantain leaf] Knt. Of course Sh. did not allude to the tropical fruit-bearing plant, but to the common plantain of our English marshy grounds and ditches. The plantain was also considered as a preventive of poison, and to this supposed virtue Romeo first alludes.
Coll.: plantain leaf] Coll. Costard calls for it in Love’s L. L., III, i, 74.

Ulr.: plantain leaf] Ulr. Romeo means, Thy remedy is as excellent for my complaint as a plantain leaf is for a broken shin. PlantJiin was used to stop the blood, but not for a fracture of a bone, to which such a remedy obviously cannot apply. Hence, when Costard, in L. L. L., calls for a plantain leaf for his broken shin, or a fellow in Ben Jonson’s “ The Case is Altered,” wants it for a broken head, it is, I think, in the same ironical sense as here. If Romeo, as the English commentators suppose, really considered plantain a good remedy for a broken bone, his words would have no sense.

Reisly.: plantain leaf] Reisly. (Plantago major) greater plantain. The leaves were, in Sh.’s time, used to heal fresh wounds, and the village herbalists now use them for the same purpose. The plant grows near the abodes of men, and commonly by waysides; hence it obtained the common name of “ way-bread.” Bartholomteus speaks of it as “healing sore wounds, and biting of wood houndes, and abateth the swelling thereof.” And Drayton, in “Polyolbion,” has “Plaintain for a sore.” Knight’s note is not correct, as the plant grows on waysides and mostly In dry places. The water plantain (Alisma plantago) grows in ditches and moist places, but this is not the plant Sh. alluded to. The figure of the plant given by Knight is unlike the common plantain.
Cham.: plantain leaf] Cham. The buck’s-horn plantain.

51.play: Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning;

52.play: One desperate grief cures with another's languish:

53.play: Take thou some new infection to thy eye,

54.play: And the rank poison of the old will die.

55.play: ROMEO : Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.
notes: Nyi.ES.: Good-den] Nyi.ES. A mere corruption of good den for good evening. This salutation was used by our ancestors as soon as noon was past, after which time, good morrow, or good day, was esteemed improper, [ Vide post II, iv, 99.] Dyce.

56.play: BENVOLIO : For what, I pray thee?

58.play: BENVOLIO : Why, Romeo, art thou mad?

59.play: ROMEO : Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is;

60.play: Shut up in prison, kept without my food,

61.play: Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.
notes: Del.: rest you merry] Del. He supposes Romeo to be a jester, from whom no rational answer is to be expected, and is about to leave him.

62.play: Servant : God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?

63.play: ROMEO : Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

64.play: Servant : Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I

65.play: pray, can you read any thing you see?

66.play: ROMEO : Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

67.play: Servant : Ye say honestly: rest you merry!

68.play: ROMEO : Stay, fellow; I can read.

70.play: 'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters;

71.play: County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady
notes: S. Walker (‘Crit.’ vol. I, p. 2): Anselme] S. Walker (‘Crit.’ vol. I, p. 2). A late writer has anticipated me in remarking that the list of invitations in Romeo and Juliet is in verse. In l. 67 he has properly supplied the deficient syllable: “Rosaline and Livia.” In l. 63 I suspect that for "Anselme" we ought to read "Anselmo." The writer in question, if I recollect right, is Mr. Courtenay.

Capell: Anselme] Capell. But Capell had long ago written thus: “How if Capulet’s list of invited be metre too? odd as it may seem, it is nearly so now; for reading "Anselm, Anselmo" and giving "Livia" her epithet (gentle, for instance), which are both proper and something more, it resolves itself into nine as complete iambicks as any in Sh., nor can be made prose without a great deal more altering than goes to making it verse.” Notes, &c., vol. II, P. iv, p. 4.

Del.: Anselme] Del. The list of guests, as Romeo reads it off and accompanies it with his own remarks—for the epithets to the names can scarcely be deemed to have been all written down by Capulet—although printed as prose in the old as well as in the late editions, is nevertheless tolerably regular blank verse.

72.play: widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely

73.play: nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine
notes: Clarke.: Mercutio] Clarke. It is noteworthy that Mercutio here figures among the invited guests, although we find him always associating with the young men of the Montague family. He is the prince’s “kinsman,” and it may be supposed is on terms of acquaintance with both the rival Houses, although evidently having greater intimacy with the Montagues than the Capulets.

74.play: uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece

75.play: Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin
notes: Clarke.: Rosaline] Clarke. This is the point in the play which testifies that Rosaline is a Capulet.

76.play: Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.' A fair

80.play: Servant : To supper; to our house.
notes: Mal.: To supper] Mal. These words undoubtedly belong to the servant, to whom they were transferred by Theobald.

83.play: ROMEO : Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.

84.play: Servant : Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the

85.play: great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house

86.play: of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine.
notes: Steev.: crush a cup] Steev. This cant expression seems once to have been common. I have met with it often in the old plays.
Coll. Verp.: crush a cup] Coll. Verp. We still say, in cant language, to crack a bottle.

Sing.: crush a cup] Sing. In The Two Angry Women of Abington, 1599: “Fill the pot, hostess, &c., and we’ll crush it!” In Hoffman’s tragedy, 1631: “ ...we’ll crush a cup of thine own country wine.” In The Finder of Wakefield, 1599, the Cobbler says: “Come, George, we’ll crush a pot before we part.”
Sta.: crush a cup] Sta. These instances might be easily multiplied.

89.play: BENVOLIO : At this same ancient feast of Capulet's

90.play: Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest,

91.play: With all the admired beauties of Verona:
notes: Coll. (ed. 2): Tut] Coll. (ed. 2). The second interjection, necessary to the metre, is from the (MS). Dyce (ed. 2). See S. Walker’s “Crit.” vol. II, p. 146 [where this reduplication is considered necessary].

92.play: Go thither; and, with unattainted eye,

93.play: Compare her face with some that I shall show,

94.play: And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

95.play: ROMEO : When the devout religion of mine eye

96.play: Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires;
notes: White.: fires] White. Modern edd. have hitherto silently read, “ to fires” on account of the rhyme to “liars;” but Q1 and Q2, though printed from different MSS., both read “ to fire” (or fier). The mere difference of a final s seems not to have been regarded in rhyme in Sli.’s day, and the reading “fires” tends to impoverish a line not over-rich.

97.play: And these, who often drown'd could never die,

98.play: Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!

99.play: One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun

100.play: Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

101.play: BENVOLIO : Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,

102.play: Herself poised with herself in either eye:

103.play: But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd
notes: Mal.: that crystal scales] Mal. The emendation, those, was made by Rowe. I am not sure that it is necessary. The poet might have used scales for the entire machine.
Knt.: that crystal scales] Knt. Scales is used as a singular noun.
Huds. Dyce (“Remarksy" &c).: that crystal scales] Huds. Dyce (“Remarksy" &c). And so it was frequently employed by the poet’s contemporaries.

Walker (vol. III, p. 223): that crystal scales] Walker (vol. III, p. 223). We might, indeed, read “that c. scale;" but this would contradict the meaning; and Dyce says, as above (and he is not likely to be mistaken). Scales is one of a number of substantives which were then used as singular nouns; arms (in the sense of armorial bearings) lists (the place of combat, so called), stocks rh shambles, breeches, colours, &c.

104.play: Your lady's love against some other maid
notes: Theobald.: lady’s love] Theobald. But the comparison was not to be betwixt the Love that Romeo’s Mistress paid him and the Person of any other young Woman: but betwixt Romeo’s Mistress herself and some other that should be match’d against her. The Poet, therefore, must certainly have wrote, “ Your Lady-love.”
Heath.: lady’s love] Heath. That is, the love you bear to your lady, which, in our language, is commonly used for the lady herself.
Sing.: lady’s love] Sing. Perhaps we should read Your lady love,
Ulr.: lady’s love] Ulr. After all, the misprint may be in the word love, and perhaps instead thereof we should read look, or laud.

Walker (vol. I, p. 255): lady’s love] Walker (vol. I, p. 255). How can your lady's love mean anything but your lady's passion for you? which would here be contrary to the fact as well as to the speaker’s meaning. Read your ladie-love; and so I find Dyce suggests.
Sta.: lady’s love] Sta. a corruption, I suspect, for “lady-love.” It was not Romeo’s love for Rosaline, nor hers for him, which was to be poised, but the lady herself, “against some other maid.”

White.: lady’s love] White. It seems as if we should read "lady-love" here; and this obvious change has been suggested by Dyce and Singer, and declared absolutely necessary by S. Walker. But the imperfect and surreptitious (Q1) has “ladyes loue," and the subsequent old copies, though printed from another MS., “ladies loue,” Sh. too, often as he had opportunity, never used “ lady-love,” if I may trust my memory, or even Mrs. Clarke’s Concordance. And I more than doubt that the compound “ lady-love” is as old as the time of Sh., although I believe the general opinion is quite the contrary.

Dyce (ed. 2): lady’s love] Dyce (ed. 2). I did not know that this was Theobald’s reading when I proposed it in my Remarks, &c. Grant White says: “I more than doubt” [sic., ut supra,] But it certainly is. Compare Wilson’s Cohlers Prophesie, 1594: “then downe came I my lady lone to finde.” Sig. D. 3.

Ktly.: lady’s love] Ktly. This is very oddly expressed, for it was the lady herself, not her love, that was to be weigihed. I doubt if Theobald’s phrase was then in use. I read "Lady and love,” the s of the MS. having been made s by the printer, as it became t in “meant” for “mean and” in All’s Well, IV, iii.

Clarke.: lady’s love] Clarke. It is possible that this may mean “ the small amount of love borne you by your lady.” Romeo has before told Benvolio that “ she hath forsworn to love,” and it may be that, in Sh.’s elliptical style, the passage means, “ let there be weighed the littfe love your lady bears you against the charms of some other maid,” &c.

105.play: That I will show you shining at this feast,

106.play: And she shall scant show well that now shows best.

107.play: ROMEO : I'll go along, no such sight to be shown,

108.play: But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

1.play: Enter LADY CAPULET and Nurse
notes: Capell: A room...] Capell. Capulet’s House. Rowe.

2.play: LADY CAPULET : Nurse, where's my daughter? call her forth to me.

3.play: Nurse : Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old,
notes: Coleridge: Nurse] Coleridge (Lit. Rem. vol. II, p. 152, ed. 1836). The character of the Nurse is the nearest thing in Sh. to a direct borrowing from mere observation; and the reason is, that as in infancy and childhood the individual in nature is a representative of a class—just as in describing one larch tree you generalize a grove of them—so it is nearly as much so in old age. The generalization is done to the poet’s hand. Here you have the garrulity of age strengthened by the feelings of a long-trusted servant, whose sympathy with the mother’s affections gives her privileges and rank in the household. And observe the mode of connection by accident of time and place, and the childlike fondness of repetition in a second childhood, and also that happy—humble ducking under, yet constant resurgence against, the check of her superiors. [Verp. Iluds. Sta.

4.play: I bade her come. What, lamb! what, ladybird!
notes: Del.: lady-bird] Del. The nurse does not apply this epithet to Juliet in the insulting sense in which the term is now applied by the vulgar, but sportively, in allusion to her fluttering hither and thither, and because she will not allow herself to be at once found when called.

5.play: God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!
notes: Sta.: God forbid !] Sta. An exquisite touch of nature. The old nurse, in her fond garrulity, uses “lady-bird” as a term of endearment; but recollecting its application to a female of loose manners, checks herself;—“God forbid!” her darling should prove such a one!

Dyck.: God forbid !] Staunton is altogether mistaken. The nurse says that she has already “bid Juliet come;” she then calls out, “What, lamb! what, lady-bird!” and Juliet not yet making her appearance, she exclaims, “God forbid!—where’s this girl?” the words, “God forbid,” being properly an ellipsis of “God forbid that any accident should keep her away,” but used here merely as an expression of impatience.

6.play: Enter JULIET

7.play: JULIET : How now! who calls?

8.play: Nurse : Your mother.

9.play: JULIET : Madam, I am here.

10.play: What is your will?

11.play: LADY CAPULET : This is the matter:--Nurse, give leave awhile,

12.play: We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again;

13.play: I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel.
notes: White: thou’s] White. “Thou shalt,” which is the reading of nearly every modern edition, destroys the rhythm, and is altogether indefensible.

14.play: Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.

15.play: Nurse : Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.

16.play: LADY CAPULET : She's not fourteen.
notes: C. A. Brown: fourteen] C. A. Brown (“Autobiographical Poems,” &c). Juliet’s extreme youth was, at the time, an apology to the audience for the boy who played so arduous a part. This guess at explaining the deviation from the originals may seem ridiculous, but it is possible.

17.play: Nurse : I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,--

18.play: And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four--

19.play: She is not fourteen. How long is it now
notes: Johnson: teen] Johnson. To my sorrow. [Sing. Coll. Haz. Iluds. White, Hal. Steev. So in Spenser’s Fairy Queen, b. i, c. ix; “for dread and doleful teen.” Halliwell. “He was chang’d in the shape of divers other things, and passed by them invisi(de); and would (no doubt) worke much woe and teene in case he should remaine alive after this scomefull illusion.” Ammianus Marcellinus, translated by Holland, 1609.

20.play: To Lammas-tide?
notes: Nares: Lammas-tide] Nares. Tide for time. It was also scrupulously used by the Puritans, in composition, instead of the Popish word mass, of which they had a nervous abhorrence. Thus, they said Christ-tide, Hallow-tide, Lamb-tide. Luckily Whitsuntide was rightly named to their hands.

21.play: LADY CAPULET : A fortnight and odd days.

22.play: Nurse : Even or odd, of all days in the year,
notes: Knt.: Even] Knt. There is not in all Sh. a passage in which the rhythm is more happily characteristic than in these speeches of the nurse, [Verp.]

23.play: Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen.
notes: Tyrwhitt: since the earthquake] Tyrwhitt. How comes the Nurse to talk of an earthquake? There is no such circumstance mentioned in any of the novels from which Sh. drew his story; it therefore seems probable that he had in view the earthquake which had really been felt in many parts of England in his own time, viz., on the 6th of April, 1580. (See Stowe’s Chronicle and Gabriel Harvey’s Letter in the Preface to Spenser’s Works, ed. 1679.)
